ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I became intensely familiar with global health funding bureaucracy and challenges. I also became more comfortable with ambiguous tasks and leaning into confusion.
I learned about the colonialism rooted in global health funding and financing, and ways in which the current financing system continues to disadvantage LMIC institutions.

1) Think about incentive design - To stay in business, international NGOs have high indirect costs and compete for as many grants as they can. Their goal is not necessarily to build sustainable organizations or have the most efficient and effective projects. This misalignment of incentives suggests the current model of funding iNGOs has serious structural problems that impede sustainability and progress.

2) Vicious Cycle - Because NICRAs are based on current indirect costs, they trap LMIC organizations in low indirect cost rates! This is part of a broader theme: being poor is expensive, and poverty is hard to escape. How can you make improvements to your organization if it does not have the funding to pay for those improvements?

3) Keep adjusting your good ideas - The 10% de minimus rate exists to relieve the organizational burden of accounting for every dollar. It is unauditable, and thus is meant to give LMIC organizations more flexibility. I think this is fundamentally a well-intentioned and good idea. The problem is 10% is not enough to cover the IDCs of any organization and using the de minimus traps LMIC organizations in low indirect cost rates. This is a good idea, but it needs revision.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the opportunity to do anything.
Weaknesses: slight lack of structure in the beginning.

I think having a more clear goal and ways in which we could reach those goals set out from the very beginning could be better for next time, as well as more guidance from the start. I also felt that I had to do most of the project work at the end without much help from my classmates because we were all busy with finals, but it was a little frustrating that these deadlines had been imposed after we finally got our gripping.

I think we struggled in the beginning defining our goal and staying organized. We spent a lot of time ramping everyone up to understand how grants even worked. This was very necessary, but maybe could have been done over the summer, so we could have jumped right in when the year started.

That said, I learned a lot about different funding mechanisms, why they are designed the way they are, and their successes and pitfalls.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I think I learned a lot about the career path I want to take in the future and I think solving a problem and learning how to conduct your own research study is valuable. We learned how to fall down and get back up.
